items.body:
Why are we using this and still using the alias definitions in the schema?

I think the point of having this is to remove the aliases, right?

e.g.

`createdAt: timestamp("created_at").defaultNow(),` to `createdAt: timestamp().defaultNow(),`
`userAddress: varchar("user_address", { length: 42 }).primaryKey(),` to `userAddress: varchar({ length: 42 }).primaryKey(),`
items.author: carletex

We might also need to tweak the "case" on seed.ts and drizzle config.

Drizzle config uses the following prop  `casing: "snake_case",`

items.body:
I imagine v2 having 50 challenges (main challenges, side quests, small challenges, etc). We have to think how are we going to use them, e.g.:

- _Manual_ render of challenges as we are doing on the Homepage 
-  _Dynamic_ render of challenges (tech tree type inside the profile?)

Probably `varchar` will give us more flexibility, but I guess it's also nice to have the list available in the front-end in some cases (`packages/nextjs/services/database/config/types.ts` will this be enough?)

But yeah, maybe having to tweak the codebase (schema) every time we add a challenge is too much?

items.body:
Thanks Rinat! Haven't tested it yet, but adding some answers / comments

> Infinite scroll table

Ok, this is probably better than pagination.

We are not fetching all of them right? (it fetches new builders as we scroll?)

> do we need sort by builder address?

No need. Sorting by Challenges / Activity is enough.

> do we need last activity in "2 days ago" format?

Yes. Working on https://github.com/BuidlGuidl/SpeedRunEthereum-v2/blob/da629a22650d59c645f1bb6c62bd99c6530caf00/packages/nextjs/app/_components/DateWithTooltip.tsx in #42

> large avatar as in sre v1?

No need 

> is table-zebra ok or again make it as v1?

Not sure yet. I'm working on the Challenge table in #42. We can unify later, so no worries for now

> Not sure how useful this table (v1 and current version) is for searching someone. Probably I can try to implement search by address/challenges completed etc.

Search is (or at least was) super useful for admins in BGv3.5. ALl the data is loaded in memory (lol my fault) but it search in the socials and ENS names (I think, since ENS are "cached" in the database)
items.author: carletex

items.body:
For that, in V1, we had a combination of `joinedBg` flag + fetching builder from the BG API.

The role "builder" was assigned when a person successfully completed a challenge (check the setChallengeStatus function)

This is something we need to talk about, but no worries since this is already merged.

Since we will be removing the JOIN BG at some point, maybe a builder is someone who has completed X challenges (and then they can do more stuff in their profile. Like customize, etc)
items.author: carletex

items.body:
> Yes, I think we need to also think how to store ENS too so we can search by it. Mabye check for ens when registering and add to db if exists?

This is what I was doing in BG v3. And a cron job to check empty ENS. But this missed "updated"  ENS. I think we can have a similar way here and then allowing people to "refresh" it. In any case, for a future PR!!

> Regarding moment.js see this https://github.com/you-dont-need/You-Dont-Need-Momentjs?tab=readme-ov-file#time-from-now and also description of the repo and comparison table. Maybe it's better to change it. I'd prefer for example [date-fns](https://www.npmjs.com/package/date-fns)

Cursor offered me a native solution, but went with momentjs. But you are right, I'll change it !! 

Since date-fsn is a bit overkill too

items.body:
Nice, I forgot that we had the disabled prop already!

Something to fix on the backend:

Let's validate that the challengeID that is being submitted is not disabled. If not, people would be able to craft a POST request with a valid signature and submit the challenges.

I guess they could also craft any valid signature with a random challenge ID (e.g. challengeId = deezNuts) and that would call `createUserChallenge` (I'm guessing that it would fail because the referenced challengeId wont' exist)

In any case, we are already validating that the user exists (not sure if it's needed, since `createUserChallenge` will fail?), let's add the challenge not disabled check.

Let's tinker and see what's the best option.

I think we could do a ENUM / TYPE here instead of string. So it helps us to keep track of the events and be more type safe.

e.g.

```
export enum PlausibleEvent {
  JOIN_BG = "joinBG",
  SIGNUP_SRE = "signupSRE",
  CHALLENGE_SUBMISSION = "challengeSubmission",
}
```

and we use them as `PlausibleEvent.JOIN_BG` when calling the function

items.body:
> Where can I read more about this?

https://neon.tech/docs/introduction/branching

The ideal scenario (let's not do it for now since it might be overkill):
1. You create a PR
2. Neon automatically creates a database branch
  - It runs `migrate`
  - seed: You can select "production" data o "seed" data to feed the database
4. Your preview Vercel points to the created database branch

For now, maybe we could do it manually: manually create a branch for a PR (e.g. batches) and import the data / tweak schema as needed... then update POSTGRES_URL for my preview branch.

items.body:
yes, leaving the id empty should automatically do it :/

> Thought about using something like uuid but I use that id for generating website and github urls

We shouldnt rely on auto-increment IDs for this, because they are not guaranteed to be sequential without gaps. If we import and then rollback, or if we add a batch and then remove it.... the database keeps an internal number of the autoincremental id `*`, so we could end up with numbers starting from a number != 0 and skipping. I just used a serial (instead of randon uuid) because we used serial in another table (but we should treat it as one. If it's confusing, we can change it)

`*` it's possible to restart that number, but in any case, we shouldn't use that ID

Even if we make sure it's always start from 0 and we don't skip any number.....something that would still happen: We create a "Stanford University Batch" (it gets assigned id = 16), and then we create "Batch 16" (id = 17)

So, options:
1. Add the github / website as fields (as you suggested to me last week)
2. We add an extra field (internalNumbering) for our typical internal batches.
3. We use the display name as the generator. e.g. "Batch 16" => lowercase / no space => batch16.buidlguidl.com

3 is a bit hacky, yes haha We could have a dynamic text below the admin form (Batch Name field) that shows the result live:

input: Bat => shows below: bat.buidlguidl.com
input: Batch 16 => shows below: batch16.buidlguidl.com
input: Standford Batch => shows below: standfordbatch.buidlguidl.com

But 1 & 2 make sense too.

items.body:
updated `postgresClient` in https://github.com/BuidlGuidl/SpeedRunEthereum-v2/pull/136/commits/aa1512191f850cd0f15abca4c721581d6035f3d2 to use `NEXT_RUNTIME`

It's not super well documented, but the variable is there https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/optimizing/instrumentation#importing-runtime-specific-code. The important thing is that it will be undefined when running scripts (or in non-NEXTJS runtimes)

I think this is clean enough. The postgres connection lives in a single source of truth, and it can be used in NextJS & scripts runtime + local & Neon database.

---

Also updated the import script for the batches: https://github.com/BuidlGuidl/SpeedRunEthereum-v2/pull/136/commits/be22eade74324714755ea1f03bde6c715680e782 e1f7f4f7afe8

- Uses batched txs. Since the data is small, I'm doing everything on a single chunk. The good thing is that it would revert if anything fails. But we should use chunks if the data is large
- Checking if the batch already exists, so we can run this script anytime we want to sync with BG3.5. I'm updating (instead of skipping) in case some prop changes (like status). I'm using the `telegramLink` as the reference, I don't think that changes... :D

Also happy to split this into two PRs if needed.

items.prTitle: create import location and social scripts
items.body:
We are being a bit nitpicky with the DB stuff (but because it's fun, and we want to learn more haha), so don't worry too much. But let me try to answer some questions

> Why rollbacks are painful? Aren't they work automatically? Well, I've asked AI and read about locking tables and hence other queries, additional i/o operation to revert and some more reasons . Just want to understand what is the main issue in our case

Imagine you want to import 100k rows (user data) into the database. If you use a `transaction` without chunks, if the row 99.999 fails (e.g. invalid data), the "automatic" rollback will happen... and if we are doing this in a production database, it can kill it / make it super slow (people using the platform will be affected)

That's why I asked: does it make sense to use tx here? We don't really need to rollback in this case (if a user fails to import, we can check what was the error... and reimport/fix that user only... no need to revert back the others). This is still hardcore (100k requests!)

That's why, for this particular use case... `batch` is the way to go (a single TX with all the data). You can also split into chunks, but since we only have ~1k users, no need.

Note: Transactions make sense when you want "all or nothing".... e.g. if one query fails it will leave the DB in a incoherent state

> Notifications system of failing queries

I haven't thought about this, but it's important. What happens if 1 query fail? Do we get a clear message in the response?

cc @technophile-04 

> As I understand main reason to use batches is when performance matters. But in our case it's just one-time operations, do we need to care about it? Or maybe using transactions has some cost?

And yes, you are right about this. We are just geeking around :nerd_face:

items.body:
> Lol for me build_builders table was bit non-intuitive but learning more it indeed seem nice optimal way of doing things having a "junction table" since there was many-many relation b/w users and builds and also we wanted isOwner which nicely fits into this relation.

Yes, this is tricky! But it's the way to go when you have `N:N` relations.
- `1:1` (just include the data in a single  table. e.g.  builder + socialGithub => builder table)
- `1:N` (create 2 tables referencing each other from N to 1: e.g. builder + challenge => builder + userChallenges tables)
- `N:N` (create 3 tables: the extra table holds the multiple references to the other two + you can add "metadata". e.g builder + build => builder + build + buildBuilder tables)

items.body:
Hey Rinat, thanks for all of this... super easy to see options now :)

Some context: In Prague, we talked a lot about the builder's portfolio in SRE. It'll be the central piece of SRE, and we plan on updating a lot (show challenges in a different way, side quest, poap / nfts, etc). So "Getting an ENS" is another quest that builders could take on.

I imagine something like:
- A builder join SRE
- Complete a few challenges
- Goes to their profile and see options for next steps 
- One of the options / side quest: (?) icon next to their address. Hover or modal click => "Hey, it seems that you don't have a ENS...blababla... check this SRE guide about ENS.....blabla"
- They get one
- Go back to their profile, and they can hit a  icon to update it.
- Now the ens name shows in their profile
- We could do the same for ENS Avatar!

(this is just the general vision for the future)

-----

Anyway, just wanted to give some context. What I think is the best approach is and we can tackle in this PR for a first iteration:

- `ens` field on user table (already in this PR) :heavy_check_mark: 
- When an user registers, check if they have ENS and store it (already in this PR) :heavy_check_mark: 
- ENS refresh button (as in #180). But I think we can merge this later on, so we can discuss it a bit more on how to display it, etc. :clock1: 
- No cron job (remove from this PR) 
- Create a script to fetch and store all the ENS for existing users, so we can run it when we merge this PR (ToDo: Let's explore if there are options to fetch multiple addresses at the same time...) :heavy_plus_sign: 

I think this is the simplest and minimal approach, and it serves our purpose of side quests.

What do you think?

items.prTitle: Create fetchOnchainData service + use waitUntil in user register route
items.body:
> Ohh yes, the only concern I have is in case in the future, if by mistake we allow an update API endpoint which doesn't have auth, then someone could exploit this function badly.

To be clear, what I was suggesting:

From the user Repository, remove `updateUserSocials`, `updateUserLocation`, `updateUserRoleToBuilder` and leave only `updateUser`

I don't think there is a risk on the endpoints, because the function will only update the fields that are allowed in the function.

e.g. in join-batch endpoint we are doing

```ts
    const updatedUser = await updateUser(user.userAddress, {
      batchId: latestOpenBatch.id,
      batchStatus: BatchUserStatus.CANDIDATE,
    });
```

So it uses the generic repo function but the fields are fixed (no way to hack the update function)

But in update-location, we are doing:

`const updatedUser = await updateUserLocation(userAddress, location);`

But we could use the updateUser function directly.

Make sense?

items.body:
> Okay, yeah it was to close it up before I open the other issues, but sure we can keep it for future tweaks.

Yeah, this would have been great! Let me give you a bit more context, so it can help in future PRs too

In SRE, we merge a bunch of PRs every week. The SRE codebase changes and grows constantly. If we want to keep it maintainable (reduce weird bugs, easy to add stuff, easy for people to work with) we need to keep the codebase clean and simple. If we allow each PR to have a little bit of "noise", we would end up with a mess in a few months.

For me, a good "landing page visual tweaks" PR, would have been a PR that tweaks some little things (spacing, sizes, colors, etc). Instead, it's a PR that added 4 files, modified another 4, and uses some vibe-coded raw JS to interact with the DOM. Plus, some of the functionality (parallax) doesn't work properly outside of macOS.

So these are the main reasons this PR hasn't been merged, and I pushed back on it. Just me protecting the codebase, nothing personal haha!

Also: If something is more than "tweaks" it's always good to open an issue / discuss on TG before tackling a PR.

---

If you want to have closure with the PR, you can remove some of the changes (parallax, etc) and focus on some style tweaks that bug you... so we merge this PR.

Then, we can focus on more high-leverage things, and go back to tweaks when that's done (and we can have a bigger discussion on how to implement some of the animations

Thanks, Andrea! hmu if you have any questions

Something like :

```tsx

      xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"

items.body:
Hey Elliott,

It looks great! (I think we touched on this in #303). 

Something to keep in mind for the next PRs: When a PR is already approved and ready to merge (in this case, waiting for some _content_ feedback) it's just better to merge and create another PR (even if it's small) to add new stuff. If not, we add extra cycles to the PR and delay shipping. 

In this case, I went ahead and did the changes myself (to avoid another extra round: feedback by me + tweaks by you + review by me)

Code changes:
- Moved `splitChallengeReadme` to a service (GitHub makes sense, though it could also fit under the Challenge util).
- Refactor `splitChallengeReadme` to make it simpler. Regex are complex enough haha. Just checking that we have a H1 + img. Some of the more defensive edge cases you added felt less important, and better to have a clear "spec" for README structure. 

These are not a big deal, but we always try to keep code as clean, simple, and readable as possible. Otherwise, little things add up, and after 25+ PRs, the codebase becomes harder to read and maintain :D

Thanks!

items.author: carletex

items.body:
Thanks both for the feedback!!! Super helpful.

Regarding the **rounding error**: I explored your suggestions and ended up with: https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-ui/pull/11/commits/c112f2812301c34f0aa52f75ed37155771e73236.

It's basically separating the display mode (what currency the UI shows) from the source mode (what currency the typed value represents). Now, toggling only flips the display without mutating the original typed value (eliminating the floating error). The component preserves the user's exact input until they actually start typing in the opposite currency mode (where we switch the source currency to match what they're now editing). 

It's making the component "smarter" and leaving the hook as it is (removing the activeValue).

Wdyt?

> What do you think guys about keeping InputBase in components and building EtherInput/AddressInput/maybe more on top of it the same way as it was before, so our inputs will have the same styles? It could be internal component without import

Yes! I think this is good idea. I might copy it from your PR.

> Not sure though if we should have two components ( internal controlled / uncontrolled).

oh no! Agree. My plan was just to create it in the PR so we can compare and test... but once we decide, let's remove the one we don't like.

Also, I think the decision is between: internally controlled (current PR, controlled inside the component) VS externally controlled (controlled by the user of the component). I don't think we want to do _uncontrolled_ (but happy to test if you think it's worth it!)

I guess what we decide should be applied to #12 too?

> useEtherInput has nothing about input. Probably we could name hooks differently. For example if name it like useEthUsdConvertation, it can be used not only in inputs

Also thought about this when creating it. Agree that's not the best naming... but in the other hand, having a the correlation between component / hook can make sense? I'm 50/50 on it :D

related: do we need `useAddressInput` hook? Or could we just have `useAddress` hook and then `Address` and `AddressInput` components using that hook?

Sorry, opening a lot of threads in the discussion haha

But thank you, this is super enriching
items.author: carletex

items.body:
> Now it works well! The only thing I noticed is that onValueChange triggers on every EtherInput's parent rerender. So the function passed to onValueChange should be memoized to avoid that.

Good catch!

I think this fixes it https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-ui/pull/11/commits/2c684b758679d1c20e06d4084e48522d5397eb5d (and the parent doesn't need to use a useCallback!). I've never used that patter before for this, but make sense?

**internall vs externally controlled**

I've been tinkering and I haven't come to a solution that I like. To make it externally controlled, you still need to pass back the converted value to the user of the component, so you have a bunch of "onChangeFunction" (value, mode, conversion). 

So my current take is (as Shiv mentioned in his comment too): Have it internally controlled (super easy to use, just a drop-in component / widget). If you want full control, you have the hook!

But I might be missing something! 

---

I'm gonna add some props (like defaultValue as Rinat suggested) to make it more functional.

Also will add the InputBase from Rinat.

items.body: Hey all! Thanks, Rinat, for putting this together. I wasn't sure whether to post the comment here or on https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-ui/issues/22. First, this is a nice approach, and it solves a lot of use cases. This is not beautiful, but it gets the job done haha ---- My only _concern_ is if we are going too far. As we talked a few weeks ago, we have the components and the hooks. With hooks, you can do whatever you want (jsx / style wise), and components will give you some defaults that work out of the box. This, from Shiv (on #22)... > There are 3 problems we need to solve for better DX: > 1. Allowing people to somehow pass a global object so that they don't need to pass the same color to each component they use > 2. Handling dark mode nicely > 3. Specific component color override. (Like they only want AddressInput to look different but EtherInput and other components should look the same) ... might be going too far. If we implement these, as this PR does, we are basically solving "everything". It feels like we are just one step away from not needing the hooks (just JSX/layout tweaks) **These are just raw thoughts, opening them for discussion.** Let me try to think about a few options from out-of-the-box solutions (less customization) to max customization (this PR) 1. **Having predefined themes**. It could just be light / dark.... or a 2/3 color palette for each mode. 2. **Root customization with CSS vars**. Same as 1 (just light / dark themes) + allow overriding those with CSS vars (Rainbowkit does this?) 3. **"Total" Control**. This PR. I think it's 2 + allow customization per component. ---- TLDR: This approach definitely solves our needs. Just let's make sure we are not overengineering things. Let me know what you all think!! Happy to have a call for this next week, too.
items.author: carletex

items.body:
Thanks for the responses!

Started with a wall of text response, but I think you both see this approach clearly, so I'd say: let's roll with it!

(I think we are assuming a lot of things tho, and we are still in a vacuum)

> (just JSX/layout tweaks)
> Umm, I don't understand this though, how could user change this if importing from the lib? Or you mean by directly copypasting component code?

I was talking about headless components / Compound components / etc. Approaches that let you control the layout of the exported component from the lib (the only thing missing from not needing hooks at all)

> Will @source inline("bg-sui-primary ...) will remain constant or we have to keep updating it? (just thinking will it be PITA for us like everytime we update the theme we need to update the sources)

We are also increasing the CSS for the user (all the classes will always be present, whether they use it or not). Maybe it's ok if these classes are not going to change a lot and there are just a few of them.

Question: Do we really want to export all the utility classes to the user?? It seems that the users will be using just the CSS tokens to override things, and you said:

> I think it's not the case since the app could have totally **different colors** and every our palette could be bad

So people will use our default colors.... or override them with their own colors (with CSS tokens), so I don't think they will use things `bg-sui-primary` in their code

So I'd go with 1 from your options, Rinat.

items.body:
We need to take a different approach here.

This breaks the [rules of hooks](https://reactjs.org/docs/hooks-rules.html#only-call-hooks-at-the-top-level) and can cause some random issues.

We want to use it like this:

```
const ethPrice = useEthPrice();
```

Then, the hook itself should have a useEffect (it runs on init and on provider change: it will only try to get the price the provider is set) & useState ([ethPrice, setEthPrice]. ethPrice would be what we return).

items.body:
@damianmarti I noticed the bug on the state because the ETH/USD price indicator on the footer wasn't working on page load.

Before it was:
```ts
state.ethPriceSlice.ethPrice = newValue;
return state;
```

This is keeping the same object (newObj === oldObj) so it wasn't triggering a re-rendering.

I also tried the merging (returning only the changed stuff) but it's not working because of the way we are organizing the slices (each slide it's inside their own object prop).

Check out the Zustand documentation:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2486142/207398482-0d4afbd9-1be2-4dd1-814f-9ef2b3c9c175.png)


https://github.com/pmndrs/zustand/blob/main/docs/guides/updating-state.md#normal-approach

They offer some other solutions (which implies installing other libs). That's why I went with this approach. We could also refactor our slices:

From
```ts
export const useAppStore = create<TAppStore>()((...set) => ({
  tempSlice: createTempSlice(...set),
  ethPriceSlice: createEthPriceSlice(...set),
}));
```

To
```ts
export const useAppStore = create<TAppStore>()((...set) => ({
  ...createTempSlice(...set),
  ...createEthPriceSlice(...set),
}));
```

This way, everything would be at the same level and we could take advantage of the merging.

```ts
  setEthPrice: (newValue: number): void => set((state): TAppStore => ({ ethPrice: newValue })),
```

Or maybe I'm missing something... What do you think?

items.body:
Hey @camdengrieh  Thanks for the PR.

> Instead of at every point in time the side effect is being used

The call is being made only when the provider changes. So it's usually once or twice. The idea of introducing polling is to have an up to date price.

Also, your approach have a problem: it's waiting 15 seconds to make the first call, and we want that to happen immediately, and then poll every X seconds. (we have the `NEXT_PUBLIC_RPC_POLLING_INTERVAL` env var BTW)

items.body:
Great work @technophile-04 and @camdengrieh !

It works perfectly. I added a few tweaks (check the commits):

**Enable/Disable polling flag on useEthPrice**
In general, the defaults should be not to hit the RPCs too hard. I added a enable/disable flag for the polling.

**Use asyn/await.**  
As a convention, we use async/await in the project (VS .then())

**Return price = 0 on error. Explicit TS type on return functions**
I think it's better if the util always return a number. Now it returns 0 when error (hope this is never the real value of ETH )

@technophile-04 Can you review & test these changes?

items.body:
Thanks for this @technophile-04. Looking great!!

Left a few review comments.

Answering to your suggestions:

> I have used daisy UI's [Collapse component](https://daisyui.com/components/collapse/) to show the read and write contract's function. Seems like daisy UI does this by using CSS only because of which in future if we need open/close state then it will be somewhat difficult to get. Please let me know if I should implement the collapsable manually with react state, happy to refactor the code :)
eg: Where we might need open/close state is changing the DownArrow icons besides read and write buttons :

It seems that Daisy has the `collapse-arrow` class. Could you try that? https://daisyui.com/components/collapse/#with-arrow-icon

BTW, **Can you make the content visible by default?** https://daisyui.com/components/collapse/#force-open

> If you look at Address input in the above video it doesn't seem to fit well since we are using the AddressInput component there.

Rn the AddressInput is not used anywhere else. So what if we tweak it as we need... and we can think about generalizing it OR abstract it in the future? let's see how that looks like!

> While Implementing the design I found repeating the same class names for different div's, is it ok if [extract these classes](https://tailwindcss.com/docs/reusing-styles#extracting-classes-with-apply) and put them inside globas.css ?

This is tricky! I'd say: If it's a group of classes that we are going to use in different component / pages, then @apply sounds good. But if it's for divs in the same component, I don't think it makes sense (for now at least!). We can always refactor later on.

> Feel free to point out bad coding practices and stuff that can be done better...happy to refactor it again!

Everything looks clean and minimal ;)

Thanks Shiv!

items.body:
Hey @rin-st 

Thanks for this! Happy to see you are interested on collaborating on SE-2 ;)

I left a couple of comments in the code review.

Also, a couple things:

**1. Tooltip always open**

Maybe I wasn't clean enough on the issues (sorry!), but we wan't the tooltip to show all the time (not only on hover) when we are in localhost & balance is 0. You can use the `tooltip-open` class

**2. Tooltip position**
> daisyui doesn't support complex tooltips, like bottom-left, only centered bottom or centered left. So I placed the tooltip to the left (only when the balance is 0)

For this, you can use the daisy `tooltip-bottom` class and add the needed Tailwind classes to look like we want. I managed to do this adding some tw classes (`before:left-auto before:right-0 before:transform-none before:content-[attr(data-tip)]`)

![rinat](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2486142/212922151-c660dfb8-e4ac-494a-9c85-66b1c5ece237.png)

You can also make the tooltip tail (the triangle indicator) a bit bigger, overriding the `--tooltip-tail` var. (6px looks good, as in the screenshot)

items.body:
```js
// The deployer account should have sufficient balance to pay for the gas fee for contract creation.
```

I think this line should go above line 15 (`from: deployer`), since it's there where we are setting the deployer account to deploy the contract. On `args: [deployer]` we are just passing constructor arguments on deploy, and can be any address (no balance needed!)

Maybe also mention:
- it's only needed for live networks (no need to worry about balance when in hardhat)
- The `yarn account` command.

Quick attempt (feel free to change anything):
```js
// In live networks, the deployer account should have sufficient balance to pay for the gas fee for contract creation. You can run the `yarn account` command to check your balance.
```

Also there is some confusion on how the screen "rolling text" works. I think the video is a bit confusing. The idea is that the text moves in an infinite loop (until you change the direction VS. changing direction when it reach the edges). I think it's called "marquee". There was a [HTML marquee](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/marquee) element, but it's deprecated.

I think we could implement it ourselves. Some vanillaJS inspiration.

Open to suggestions... and also I'm asking Andrea.

items.body:
Thanks @KcPele & @technophile-04 

From the issue description https://github.com/scaffold-eth/se-2/issues/142:
> A way to read **past events** from a given contract, and listening to new events.

I think that this implementation only listens to new events, while the user is on the page. Which is super handy! But _I think_ we also want to be able to retrieve past events. e.g. we want to list all the token transfers.

SE1 does it. But I think wagmi doesn't have a hook for it. Maybe it's too heavy and people are supposed to use another approach for it (like subgraphs)?

In any case, we can discuss on the existing issue and merge this.

Maybe change the hook name to `useScaffoldEventSubscriber` or similar?

Thoughts? Thanks!!

items.body:
While I'm playing with this, some thoughts:

. It'll take some time to get this right, but let's keep exploring this approach.
- wagmi/cli as @technophile-04 suggested, might be a good solution when everything works :D It's super new, so let's see how it evolves
- _(from my fuzzy brain)_ I still think there should be a way to tweak `useDeployedContractInfo` / or passing a TS generic (with the ABI?) somewhere to get the types for the contract data. Anyway, it's no clear in my head right yet haha. Converting JSON to TS, seems to be needed.

**The biggest DX issue that we have right now:**
![b](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2486142/220172561-d4385262-c151-4473-8beb-dbd77f51a03f.png)
![a](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2486142/220172568-9c775245-f3be-4de3-9e1e-c018df8dc32e.png)

Since `data` in unknown we get the `ReactNode` error. It won't happen if data is `any`. Can we make that happen as v0.1? Creating an issue for it. https://github.com/scaffold-eth/se-2/issues/189

If we fix that, we won't have autocompletions / type inference, but at least you can use data freely.

> remove generated folder from gitignore, since typings rely on generated/hardhat_contracts file

The best solution would be that the generation happens on the build step, i.e. running the hardhat node + deploy on build.

Thanks all! I'll keep iterating on this.
items.author: carletex

items.body:
> Why do we need to maintain uncontrolled behavior? For users who will decide to use forms?

It started with the `AddressInput` component. Adding the uncontrolled behav was basically adding this line (+ some checks):
```ts
  const currentValue = value !== undefined ? value : address || "";
```

Besides using forms (on regular HTML inputs, you have the option of use them as controlled VS uncontrolled, even if the controlled way is the recommended way)... I liked the idea of adding `<AddressInput />` into the page with no props and you could see the component doing its work (ens resolution, ens avatar, blockie, etc). Maybe a silly thing, but adding it was trivial.

I though it was a good idea to for the `EtherInput` component too. But it's more complex by nature, and yep, the controlled input was broken (in a weird way) but also working in "controlled" & "uncontrolled" mode (in a weird way :D)

I like the component refactor in this PR (way more clean now), but I don't think it's working as I understand it should:

**Uncontrolled:**
- `<EtherInput />` This doesn't work. It works on main.

**Controlled**
- `<EtherInput value="12" />`. This shows the correct value of 12 (and its USD value), but it let you change the ETH value on the input (it shouldn't in a controlled component). Same error in main (+ doesn't show the init value). It doesn't make sense to use the component like this tho, but, it tell us that we are not handling the "controlled" input the right way.
- `<EtherInput value={amount} onChange={v => setAmount(v)} />`. This works perfectly, better than the exiting main, since it takes in consideration the init value.


> upd. It looks like you changed all the inputs behavior to controlled in https://github.com/scaffold-eth/se-2/pull/220 . Probably we're wasting time trying to make it work for uncontrolled

It all boils to this. What do you all think? My opinion:

- Make uncontrolled work if it doesn't take too much effort / complexity. 
  - If it does, nix it (I think #220 does it by making onChange mandatory)
- Make the controlled version work as it should. (#220 has the same problem, where you can still change the input on a hardcoded value and not update).

In any case, we are not wasting time! :P These tinkering / discussions are good for the project.

Thank you all <3
items.author: carletex

items.body:
I lean into having both, as any HTML input that you might use in React.

But after reading your comments and following the simple & minimal motto of SE-2....let's go with **controlled only**. We can always change our mind in the future.

We need to tweak this PR to make it totally controlled. Right now `<EtherInput value="1" />` let's you change the value. It should have the same behaviour as `<input type="text" value="hola" />`

Thanks

items.body:
DX perspective:

When I use the component, it's weird that only `onChange` is required. In my mind, "value" and "onChange" should be required.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2486142/224305981-8652b33c-72c4-4ace-b0c1-a2795a7c52f9.png)
My IDE autocompletion

With value required:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2486142/224306072-887da08e-743d-4929-9f4e-1f5d072ab154.png)

I see the use case the other way around: onChange not required (for disabled / read-only inputs) if we want to make that happen. But I don't see why you would want to NOT provide a value.

This is going to be the 99.9% use case for controlled components, right?:

```tsx
const [sendValue, setSendValue] = useState("");

<EtherInput placeholder="Amount to send" value={sendValue} onChange={value => setSendValue(value)} />
```

Am I missing something? Thanks!

After pulling the threads on this, some notes:
- The only instance where we are passing a custom signer, is for the hardhat faucet (where we want to send funds from a hardhat account with funds). Can we think about other use case? Since we are in the front-end, 99.99% of the times we'll want to use the connected signer (besides the faucet, and maybe a exotic build where we do deterministic private key derivation or something)
- `getBlockExplorerTxLink` doesn't return anything for the local chain (the only instance where we are using a custom signer for the transactor :thinking: )

- Maybe an util like `getChainFromChainId` that returns a wagmi Chain for a given Id?

In any case, no need to make any updates rn!! just thinking out loud and pointing out some possible inconsistencies. Maybe we made some past decisions that could use some refactors for the sake of consistency / simplicity / better DX.

items.body:
> Moved scaffold.config to root and same is being utilised by both next and hardhat

This is great! I think having an unique config file it's more dx friendly. A few thoughts/questions: 

- Could/Should we add a single source of truth here about networks? We have the `networks.ts` file on next, and we use the networks also in `hardhat.config.ts`. I'm just wondering if we could define a network object with all the data we need in scaffold.config, for hardhat & next (wagmi) to use. "Networks" feel like a key & transversal piece for SE-2 (or any dApp)
- Should we also support env vars in the config file? Specifically for secrets, since people are going to commit the config file. Things like "DEPLOYER_PRIVATE_KEY" or even alchemy/infura keys that could live in config.
```ts
const scaffoldConfig: ScaffoldConfig = {
	targetNetwork: chain.hardhat,
	pollingInterval: 30000,
        deployerdPrivateKey: process.env.DEPLOYER_PRIVATE_KEY
} as const;
```
I think we'll just need the dotenv package on the root. Handling all the config & env vars in the root seems more friendly. I think it will work on Vercel when manually defining the env vars in their UI.

This is just me thinking out loud, would love to hear your view on it.

> btw I came across some patterns where people have created config directory similar to nextjs and harhdat where all the base configurations live like .eslintrc, .tsconfig etc, just wanted to put here since we are in "refactoring phase" :) and also we can put scaffold.config inside it. I like the way currently it is now but would love to know others thought
> I'm used to those types of config files being at the root of their package, that's where I would generally look for them, so it doesn't bother me personally.

Since this is a monorepo with two packages, it also doesn't bother me having separate config files. But I've also seen monorepos with a **shared** (or config) directory.. I guess it's an alternative to having everything shared in the root (when is too bloated). It's definitely something that we should explore, but maybe in the future / another PR? This PR is already a big refactor.

**Proposal**

items.author: carletex
carletex

items.body:
Great job @technophile-04 

I think we are not far, but still doesn't feel 100% right to me.

### 1. Vercel root directory

![Screenshot 2023-03-16 at 2 40 32 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/80153681/225569118-da97971f-96ba-4dbd-b45d-d2a1ccc08fcf.jpg)

It might be like a little thing, but for me, it decreases the deploy experience by a bunch. I tried to search for options for the CLI / vercel.json config file, but it doesn't seem that you can provide a default `root directory` option. The `--cwd` option doesn't work either.

Not sure what we could try.

### 2. .env vars

> If we plan to have global env's then implement them, checkout out the last section for resistance faced https://github.com/scaffold-eth/se-2/pull/231#issuecomment-1470438008

I think we need .env vars for secrets. 

**Answer 1**
Right now on `scaffold.config.ts`:
```ts
const scaffoldConfig: ScaffoldConfig = {
  // ....
  deployerPrivateKey:
    "0xac0974bec39a17e36ba4a6b4d238ff944bacb478cbed5efcae784d7bf4f2ff80",
 // ..
} as const;
```

and then `const deployerPrivateKey = process.env.DEPLOYER_PRIVATE_KEY ?? scaffoldConfig.deployerPrivateKey;` on `hardhat.config.ts`. It's confusing, since we have the `deployerPrivateKey` on the config file and it's not clear that people need to create a `.env` file inside the hardhat folder

I think it should be:
```ts
const scaffoldConfig: ScaffoldConfig = {
  // ....
  deployerPrivateKey: process.env.deployerPrivateKey || 
    "0xac0974bec39a17e36ba4a6b4d238ff944bacb478cbed5efcae784d7bf4f2ff80",
 // ..
} as const;
```
So people can create a `.env` file in the root folder (we might have a `.env.example`) that it's meant for secrets. And secrets consumers just read `scaffoldConfig.deployerPrivateKey`. Same for `alchemyApiKey` and `etherscanApiKey`.

And make sure people understand that they should never use `scaffoldConfig` to store secrets directly (even if we are doing so :sweat_smile:)

Maybe we could pass the secrets/env vars like this to Vercel:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2486142/225676113-6b2d92e7-55d5-4967-ae80-aa3356b655a5.png)

If people create/update an env var from the Vercel UI, they will take effect if they rebuild (they are being used on the scaffold.config.file)?

**Answer 2**

Use `scaffold.config.ts` only for public variables (targetNetwork && pollingInterval), and handle the secrets env vars in its own package:
- **Hardhat.**. Same as in main (.env file)
- **NextJS**.  We'd replace `.env.*` with the config file, but people could still use `.env` / `.env.local` / Vercel UI to set up secrets and use them in their API routes or whatever.

This way we don't mix config & secret env vars... and things might be simpler.

> Handle this properly https://github.com/scaffold-eth/se-2/pull/231#discussion_r1132625398

This is not a big deal for now. We could create an issue for that refactor.

---

Definitely having a root config file makes things a bit more complicated. I'll be up for it if we find a nice balance. But https://github.com/scaffold-eth/se-2/pull/231#issuecomment-1471517364 is still on my mind.

Thoughts?

items.body:
Ok, a recap so I understand.

We need to get the actual targetNetwork.id value (and not the widened type) for #202 to work. We solved that using the `satisfies` operator.

The issue then is that TS complains when we compare `scaffoldConfig.targetNetwork.id` (resolved to a specific number) with another specific number. "Types have no overlap". We need to assert the type (as number) to remove the error.

I don't love the casting here, seems counterintuitive, since you are working with the wagmi Chain type, but it's not really resolving as such. But I could live with it.

Just throwing another idea, and see if you all think it's worth implementing it:

As we had before https://github.com/scaffold-eth/se-2/pull/246, have a `getTargetNetwork` util than returns the selected network in config:

```ts
const getTargetNetwork = (): Chain => { }
```

So benefits I see:
- It solves this error.
- We can directly access the config when we need the specific value (for #202)
- We could extend the targetNetwork value there (e.g. adding the colors)
- It's a wrapper, so if we ever change the way of defining the targetNetwork, we'd just need to change it here (e.g. we move the scaffold.config to the root).

Shiv already mentioned why he decided to remove this extra function in https://github.com/scaffold-eth/se-2/pull/246#discussion_r1139234630. But with this in mind, maybe our reasoning is different.

Anyway, not feeling super strong about this, just wanted to put it out there and see what you all think.

Happy to merge as it's.

cc @technophile-04 @rin-st @sverps

items.body:
Thanks @sverps From #249 > I think a more intuitive behavior is to disable the hook when we know it would result in an error, and only call the contract function when the params are good. That way, the types force a dev to plug in correctly typed variables for args, and when a user using the UI does some action (i.e. fill in a form) that actually provides a value for the variables, only then is the actual contract function called. In this PR we are only checking if one of the args is undefined, so yes, we avoid a bunch of console errors in the case that a **read Hook has multiple arguments and the builder uses a form** (until the user starts typing in the last argument input). If it only takes 1 args: ```tsx const [address, setAddress] = useState(""); const { data } = useScaffoldContractRead({ contractName: "YourContract", functionName: "userGreetingCounter", args: [address], }); return ( <> setAddress(v)} />

{data?.toString()}

) ``` In this case, you'd still get all the errors, right? You might save *1* error if you use `useState();` on load. > Reduce contract calls (or at least reduce triggers of the wagmi hook) Yes, I think the contract is never called (RPC calls not fired) until the args are OK. We just get the errors from Ethers (that wagmi uses under the hood) --- We can definitely merge this, but I guess a better solution could be to check if the args are **valid** depending on their type (Address, number, etc) Thoughts?

items.body:
> It remains a bit strange that wagmi hooks don't seem to handle this scenario nicely.

The prepare hooks can't know when to refresh! They only refresh when the arguments of `usePrepareContractWrite` change, or when you call `refetch`..... but not when the contract data changes.

The 3 options we have explored:
1. Deps. Let the user define what the deps are (not DX friendly)
2. Refetch whenever a contract finish a write op. (with the global state). I like this option
3. Refresh on every block. Effective, but RPC expensive.

items.body:
This is cool, but we need to handle the USD conversion in this component.

If people see 1 MATIC, and they click the Balance, they will get ~1900 USD (which is the ETH Price). So I see two options:

1. Fast: Disable the toggle funcionality when != ETH
2. Slow: Get the price from uniswap (as we are doing for ETH in `fetchPriceFromUniswap`) and display the correct conversion. We'd need to tweak a bunch of stuff
   - useEthPrice => useNativeCurrencyPrice();
   - state.setEthPrice / getEthPrice => state.setNativeCurrencyPrice / getNativeCurrencyPrice
   - Add the uniswap contract addresses in NETWORKS_EXTRA_DATA (if different that the ETH one).
   - etc...

Anyway up to you. Happy to merge the first option, and leaving the second one for another PR.

> I think this can be improved because its kind of confusing setting fallback here(which won't work and works only for one condition when on mainnnet) since kind of conflicting guard check above (am I missing something ? ) :
> Also I think for consistency, lets move WETH (0xC02aaA39b223FE8D0A0e5C4F27eAD9083C756Cc2) address to networks.ts and add :

It will work for every network that has ETH as their native currency, not only mainnet! There are a lot of them: goerli, sepolia, arbitrum, optimism, etc.

That's why I asked Kevin to have that as the default (to avoid replicating it in multiple places in that file... and also it will work for wagmi chains not listed on `NETWORKS_EXTRA_DATA` and have ETH as a native currency).

Anyway, not feeling super strong about it. Happy to reconsider :D

items.body:
Thanks for the catch and the PR @moltam89  And thanks @technophile-04 for the fix suggestion. I think it could be the simple/best approach.

> JSON.stringify - This one works correctly, but ESLint doesn't like it and I'm not sure if we want to disable it for this.

IMO, ESLint rules are just there to give you some hints: "react-hooks/exhaustive-deps" is trying to warn you that you might be missing some dep.... which we are not! We are using JSON.stringify(dep), but the linter is not capable of inferring it. Using this method might be problematic on big objects / objects with circular references... but in this case, they will be small objects with one/few props.

My vote would be to add:
// eslint-disable-next-line react-hooks/exhaustive-deps

Thanks for taking your time on this PR.

[Hardhat deploy](https://github.com/wighawag/hardhat-deploy) already have both flags, so ideally we don't want to bloat the repo with extra commands (and new libs) that we don't really need.

`yarn deploy --reset` works, but I noticed that `yarn deploy --watch` works (detects changes in contracts/ and deploy/)... BUT doesn't run the `generateTsAbis` script. It's because the `--watch` doesn't let the deploy command exit.

We should find a fix for that!

Hey all! I've been testing this, and everything seems to be working great. Amazing work @portdeveloper and @technophile-04. This is going to be a great addition.

I think we need to fix some styling before merging. I promise these will be the latest requests :D Since it's a really big PR, I'm sure we'll find some issues later, but we can handle them in a different PR.

### 1. Everything is huge

Most of the buttons, text, tabs, etc are really big compared to other (existing) elements of the page.

Eg: 
![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/215738a1-866b-4a7d-8dd3-be46977db0f5)
![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/c5b9dfa6-c7c5-4f98-9d92-742ab32ec8ac)

Let's remove all the `*-lg` stuff. It should be regular sizes (no modifier) and in some cases `*-sm` (buttons, maybe some texts)

### 2. Light mode

2.1 There is no background color here, all is floating on the page (dark mode looks great tho):
![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/7fad23bb-8430-49bc-9a2a-43f58d635579)

2.2 Not important but the table has no zebra style (maybe we need to tweak something in the tailwind styles?). Also, no need to tackle this here if we don't want to.
![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/76fe5e89-6cb0-4301-9ad7-02eb357019f3)

----

1 and 2.1 are bugging me, but other than that... everything looks great.

I'm happy to work on this too, if you guys are not sure about some of the stuff.

items.body:
Yep, it's a good discussion to have. The three options:

1. As Pablo was suggesting. They will need to update the types tho (not super big deal, since it's right on top)
2. `custom?: Record<string, any>;` as Samuel suggested. I like it.
3. `} & Record<string, any>;` second option that Samuel suggested. I don't like this one since any string will work (you can misspell any of the required config props and won't get an error).

I think it should be between 1 or 2.

1: If we see "ScaffoldConfig" as the _Custom App config_ that the user just created (e.g. similar to Header.tsx: it's a component from the _custom app_)
2: If we see "ScaffoldConfig" as an "immutable" (but extendable) config from the app (e.g. similar to Address.tsx: it's a component from _scaffold-eth_)

Not sure if I'm making sense :D

items.body:
Thanks for the feedback and the help @rin-st.

> btw I was trying to use npx create-eth@latest from se-2 folder. If I use it from outside git repo it works as expected

Yep, this was happening when running it inside an existing git repo (because of the postinstall yarn hook). Your fix works perfectly, but it leaves the `yarn.lock` file uncommitted (changed after running `yarn install`**), so we decided to take a different approach (git init before yarn install, but add & commit after yarn install) and it seems to work. @technophile-04 will push in a bit.

** This is expected since we have an empty `yarn.lock` file, to avoid conflicts when we have a bunch of extensions. So it's generated on the first install. In package.json files, we changed ^ for ~, so with packages bugfixes there is less risk of something breaking (we tried to do exact versions in package.json, but for some reason the peer-dependencies weren't installing)

> On Windows (both my desk and laptop) it's working like a charm when I choose hardhat, but when I choose foundry, I got problems to yarn chain.

Thanks @Pabl0cks ! Yes, this happens because people need to install foundryup (that contains anvil and some other tools) in their **system**. What we are going to do is check if they have it installed and if not show a message hinting them to install.

We'll be pushing (& publishing) in a bit.

Thanks all!

items.body:
Thanks for testing it and the feedback @schmidsi !

> I personally don't like submodules.

Same! We had some issues making them work with the cli too. But I think there is no way around it with foundry, since it's the way it manages its deps.

> packages/nextjs/generated/deployedContracts.ts is marked as changed. 

This was changed after you run `yarn deploy` right? That file contains "the artifacts" (address + abi) of the contracts deployed with SE-2, so you need them in order to interact with those contracts in the frontend. Doing it in the build step will be tricky since the source of truth lives on the hardhat package (when you deploy the front-end you only deploy the `nextjs` package). See this discussion also: //github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/issues/369
items.author: carletex

items.body:
![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/33f65e15-f578-4550-8b8e-f2d7fcd26705)

I don't want this branch to diverge too much from main, so I think it's a good practice to merge from main once in a while.

The merge it's pretty straightforward (merge from the UI) if non-tricky files are changed (any hook, components, etc) but you have to do it in your machine if there are files like package.json, yarn.lock, template files etc modified. In this case, it was easy, just "accepting ours" for those two files.

items.body:
Hey @webthethird 

I watched your presentation on BTF and it was pretty cool. Thanks for this!

In SE-1, there are hundreds of branches that people contributed, showcasing a huge variety of use cases for web3 apps that people could use as templates.

In SE-2, we didn't embrace the same model, since we don't think branches are meant for that. They are now primarily used for isolating feature development & bug fixing. This helps us maintain a clear and organized development workflow.

We don't have a great system for showcasing community builds right now (but it's on the roadmap!**). I think the best you can do is create your build in your BG profile (https://app.buidlguidl.com/) so people can find it in the /builds route. 

** The idea is to improve the current /builds page, with tagging / filter search / etc.

Thanks again!

items.body:
> Now due to https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/issues/419, our version viem exports from "dist" but when we upload to vercel it uses new viem where the location from which it is exported is changed

Yeah, we really need to tackle this issue, where that deps local version != deployed version. https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/pull/444 is a solution, but I'm not 100% sold on it. I'll comment soon.

The other option is locking the version in `package.json` but I feel you guys don't like that? I don't see any issues taking that approach. When we want to update we just update the version manually (which arguably makes us more conscious about updating / the version we are updating to), or even temporarily adding `^` before updating a given dependency and locking it later. Maybe not as convenient as just running `yarn update` on a given dependency... by it's definitely better than having a version mismatch between the local & prod env. Am I missing something?

----

Also for this PR: Shouldn't we just update viem (so it saves in the .lock file executed locally). It'll still fail for SE-2 forks/clones, but it'll be fixed on fresh installs.

Thanks!
items.author: carletex

items.body:
> Also for this PR: Shouldn't we just update viem (so it saves in the .lock file executed locally). It'll still fail for SE-2 forks/clones, but it'll be fixed on fresh installs.

> As mentioned by Rinat https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/pull/444#issuecomment-1732584888 addingPrettify locally works and also it makes sense to localize this "helper type" since it is famous and we also shouldn't rely on Viem to export this for us because they might move to another place in future/change name/remove without mentioning it since its not their main api

Make sense!

Merging this! but will still love to hear your thoughts here: https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/pull/541#issuecomment-1733419009

@technophile-04 @rin-st @Pabl0cks

items.body:
Hey @technophile-04! Thank you so much for the write-up & context. Now I see everything more clearly. Some of the stuff you mentioned was on my notes (I was planning to post it in the pnpm PR, but will do it here)

I had a wall of text haha, but since you already did a great job given all the context, let me just comment on it and propose next steps.

> main issue : "Version mismatch between the local & prod env" i.e. https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/issues/419

Exactly. This is the most critical issue. We thought that having separate lock files would fix it (which it will!), but It was weird to me that not so many people were using that feature (and is not present in other package managers) & it seemed a bit unstable.

This PR fixes the issue (you are 100% right, it's not an issue when connecting repo in Vercel UI) in a better way :rocket: 

### CLI

> Locking versions in package.json makes sense there since we don't have .lock files and up for it  (We already using ~ their instead of ^)
> Not sure about adding .lock files by default. I mean currently its fine because we just have plain SE-2  next but when add extensions like TheGrpah then we will be needing to add more packages to plain SE-2 next which might not be easy

Agree with what you said. We can lock versions in package.json (or ~)... and yeah, it can get messy pre-generating `.lock` files (as you said, extensions might add some deps to other extensions). Maybe, if we want to super-optimize, we could generate a couple of global `.lock` files (nextjs + hardhat / nextjs + foundry). It'd improve performance for the most used option (but this is future future haha)

so...

### PNPM

If I remember correctly the main reason we started thinking about PNPM was **the issue that this PR is fixing**:

> Also just mentioning pnpm here  (It's workspaces has this option to create separate lock files) ....I tried it out and its really good also we might also benefit from it using it in our CLI due to its some what faster installations

(Shiv on https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/issues/419#issuecomment-1637115179)

Yes, I get it, pnpm is fancy and faster (especially if we disabled the per-package lock files) but I don't think it's worth it at this point. It has some issues on Windows (the env vars), and IT'S DAMN HARD TO WRITE, READ AND SAY haha 

So now I change my 51% (pnpm) / 49% (yarn) vote to 1% (pnpm) / 99% (yarn)... and I'd keep an eye on Bun. It could be a nice option to improve performance. BTW, I think yarn gets a lot of shit, but I think v3 is good & fast enough.

Thoughts?

items.body:
Thanks for the investigation @technophile-04 !

Some more stuff that I found (`yarn why` is great): 

This is the **CLI**:
![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/29218295-3b01-4ff1-b456-6cd476f99fdf)

This is **main**:
![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/883e1c2f-43ff-46e1-9f41-c0888ea26704)

In CLI we have 2 diff versions because:
- newer version of the VERCEL package (28.15.1 => 28.15.7)
- newer version of types/react-copy-to-clipboard (5.0.4 => 5.0.5)

These two use a newer version of types/react (18.2.24).

-----

What I did then is to remove the `~` in the package.json file (only for next), so it installs the same version as in the lockfile (at least the top dependency!):

![image](https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/assets/2486142/706f3316-1bf9-4b35-b85c-34c815abe601)

So, it the vercel dep is gone, but not the clipboard one. I think this is exactly what @rin-st was talking about here: https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/pull/541#issuecomment-1734204842

Even if we install the same top dep (5.0.4) it uses a newer version of `@types/react`. Why? Because package.json file of `@types/react-copy-to-clipboard`:

```
    "dependencies": {
        "@types/react": "*"
    },
```

:cry: 

----

So not having a lockfile is tricky.

We can remove `~`, but things can always break in the future because a new release of sub-dependency updates and breaks something.

A decent solution:
- Remove `~`
- Have some kind of automated testing that runs every day, installs SE-2 with different options, runs some commands, and checks errors. That way we can identify issues early.

Not ideal, but better than nothing.

Thoughts? 

--

Also check this comment: https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/pull/555#discussion_r1345630966

This could help for errors related to `@types` packages
items.author: carletex

items.body: Maybe having `^` instead of `~` or a fixed version for all the `@types` packages could solve this issue (and future issues too?)
items.author: carletex

items.body: It seems pretty standard on all the sub-deps in `@types` packages.
items.author: carletex

items.body:
@technophile-04 I think I understand what you are saying.

doing `sum : latest` is not a very good practice for any lib (but it seems common for @types libs). But yeah, the risk is there

> It will be really hard for us to debug too right ? Since A might using sum very deep down which causes some of A api's break which we are using in SE-2 also this will be hard to catch in automated tests?

If we have good automated tests, I guess we could detect that something is not working (deploy, start, checking types, etc), right? And the we can investigate the root of it and fix it (it'll prolly be a versions that needs to be updated)

I think I'm gonna update @types to ^ for now.

> Also btw I think we should make a quick another patch PR cli because npx create-eth@latest is broken now because of this

Maybe we can merge this one? I'll send the  update in a bit.

Something that we could explore in some cases => [yarn resolutions](https://yarnpkg.com/cli/set/resolution) (so we can set the version of any sub-dependency):

```
"resolutions": {
   "@types/react": "18.2.21"
}
```

items.body:
> Downside of putting everything in the same file is running yarn deploy seems to overwrite the whole file, and thus it removes any manually added external contracts. So this approach requires changing 99_generateTsAbis.ts to parse the existing file and ensure external contracts are kept. This would require some sort of deep merge, which might not always do exactly what the user expects (e.g. a user that changes a contract name might still see his old contract show up in addition to the newly named one, since our deepMerge would not know if an existing definition is an old deployment, or a user added external contract).

This is a great point.

If we can figure out the Types for the 2-files approach, it's definitely the way to go (`deployedContracts.ts` & `externalContracts.ts`). 

Thanks @technophile-04 & @sverps !!

items.prTitle: Add pooling interval to EventHistory hook
items.body:
> I'm not sure, because if you want faster polling when using hardhat you just change the value at the scaffoldConfig file.

The thing is that we don't use the scaffoldConfig polling value when we are on hardhat / foundry (check the wagmiConnectors file Shiv linked), since we want to be as fast as possible. The default seems to be 4000 ms https://wagmi.sh/react/providers/configuring-chains#pollinginterval-optional

> If you use some special value for hardhat and then the user starts using a real blockchain, and the events start loading slowly, maybe the user doesn't understand why they were loading faster before.

Yep, this might be true! But it's how we are doing it rn :/ We have a warning in scaffoldConfig tho:

```
  // The interval at which your front-end polls the RPC servers for new data
  // it has no effect on the local network
```

So for the sake of consistency, it might be a good idea to set 4000 for local chains?

What do you all think?

Addreth is really cool (btw, see https://x.com/_carletex_/status/1718598466841067644?s=20) but for now we don't plan on adding an external library for it. We have our own set of components that we might extract into an npm package at some point (that's why they are inside the `scaffold-eth` folder in the `components` folder).

Also, as we said in the contributing docs, it's better if you create an issue first so we discuss & decide (so you don't have to do unnecessary work)

items.body:
So what's the verdict on this one? :D

If we want to be on the same page as wagmiv2 / TanStack, I think I like this option:

```
const { writeContractAsync: writeYourContractAsync } = useScaffoldWriteContract("YourContract");
```

At least we'd have a write instance for each contract. 

And if we don't want to follow wagmiv2 / TanStack, I guess we could keep the same API.. but it feels a bit contrived?
items.author: carletex

items.body:
No option has all the upside, so we have to make compromises haha.

My ranking is:

**1.** v2 approach: `const { writeContractAsync: writeSetGreetingsFunc, data: setGreetingsTxHash } = useScaffoldWriteContract("YourContract");

I like this one because it's aligned with wagmi / tanStack. When using multiple instance, we have the issue that Rinat was mentioning (is loading / data), but It's not terrible and can be worked out.

**2.** v1 approach: I like this too. The good thing is that the API doesn't change... but it can get confusing with wagmi.

**3.** Having 2 hooks for writing to a contract. This is the only option that I don't like. I think it'll just make things more confusing.

We can ofc merge one of the options.... and adapt if we people don't like it.
items.author: carletex

items.body: Because they do the same... but in a different way. I don't see the point of that (+ bloat + confusing the user on which one to choose) and I think it goes against the simplicity motto we have for SE-2

> Usefull when I share https://frames-se2.vercel.app/builders lol but not sure if it makes that much sense

Do you think this is a use case for Frames? From what I've seen, people create a _single_ frame for an app (typically more complex than what we are doing here). Abstracting "framRelativeRoute" + "frameBtnLabel"  seems a bit too much.

If they want to build a real frame, they'll need to create a backend route with the dynamic steps, so these abstractions won't serve much.

My initial idea was to make a simple/silly "frame" so people could see it out of the box, and tweak as needed. But merging this PR might not be a good idea after all :D

items.body:
Thanks for the review @rin-st !

> who remembers why we added that price > 0 condition?  Looks like it's redundant

The USD mode only makes sense when we have a price for the native currency. If it's loading (or if the fetch fails) it doesn't make sense to show the USD mode... since you won't be able to convert to the native currency (which is what we want for any onchain operation / show balance, etc). So I think that was the reason.

> Rename usdMode to defaultUsdMode and use that value as default in useState. Remove useEffect. (I prefer this)

This will only work if we ignore my previous comment (the price condition). I agree that `defaultUsdMode` might be a better name.

> Remove inner usd/eth logic. Use only usdMode prop (or mode)

I don't like this one since it'd require people to do their logic for the basic toggle USD / ETH.

---

I'm not sure if these components need a refactor, but like you said, it should probably happen in another PR.

I just created this one as a hotfix, to tackle a bug that is currently happening on main (and tried to be consistent with other components)

Update: pushed https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/pull/1008/commits/3ae16c4407f77479fe889f2b7ad537992b9c7ec4 and it seems to be working.

This is the simplest way that I found to load the decrypted PK in memory and run everything as usual. I think `deploy` (when a network != hardhat/localhost) is the only place where we actually need the PK. (well maybe for hardhat scripts too).

So everything runs as always, but when you deploy it check if the network is specified. If so, decrypt the PK, load it into the env, spaw a process and run the deploy command as usual. 

Added a ToDo on the top PR comment (yarn account:import)

Please test, and let me know if you find a better way or if I'm missing something. Also @Pabl0cks , could you check on Windows?

items.body:
> but not sure what's the best solution here is.

Not sure either, but sharing some thoughts here as well. 

I think the Sepolia one is the most problematic (noticed this when trying to deploy from hardhat when we had the public RPCs... it was always failing giving weird errors). The problem is that the RPC is not _failing_ (where the fallback would work)... it's just returning incorrect stuff.

I guess **wevm** people noticed it too because they changed it on `viem` last month https://github.com/wevm/viem/commit/79a183046b92f90d3e8ce707fe1e28b4523d7e5e. I guess it'd come with the newer versions of wagmi/view.

A couple of solution could be:
1. If this is mainly Sepolia, let's just update and leave the RPC order as it was.
   - PROS: 
     - Our alchemy key won't suffer
   - CONS: 
       - public RPCs tend to fail
       - If people change to use their alchemy key... it'd still fail because it's the fallback (A weird hack would be to detect if a different API is being used... if so, make alchemy the default)
2. If it's a general thing, let's tweak the order. 
   - PROS:
     - Works most of the time (unless limits are hit)
   - CONS:
     - People killing our RPC

items.prTitle: Encrypt deployer PK on .env file (when using hardhat)
items.body:
If you forget your password:

- you run `yarn account` and it'll ask for your password. So you won't send anything
- If we don't require a password, you might send it... and then (e.g. when you deploy) you'd realize that you don't remember the password and the funds might be lost.

That was the only reason I did it like this.

Happy to reconsider.

items.body:
Hey all! 

I spend the morning with Pablo & Shiv (live in Spain!) tinkering with this.

The conclusion: non-deterministic things sucks :D

We tested 3 versions of the rules files (aso Sonnet 3.5 and 3.7. 3.7 was usually better):

1. Port's version (you can rollback to this commit to test https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/pull/966/commits/6033ca669cbc5cc1b2ee21569a03dfba99d6c064)

- This was fast, and got the hooks right (sometimes not in the first try, but it auto-fixed)
- Besides the read/write hooks, it didn't use the "scaffold-way" most of the times: Address component, yarn start (was doing yarn dev inside nextjs folder), etc.

2. Full LLM file pasted into the rules: https://docs.scaffoldeth.io/llms-full.txt

- This was a slower and results similar to Port's (but was slightly better on the scaffold-way)

3. The current version of this PR: https://github.com/scaffold-eth/scaffold-eth-2/pull/966/commits/a20fb77f8f29db55b6efcae121a64847749db293

We came to this version after a few tries and I think it has the best of both. Fast & scaffold-aware.


I have to say that most of the tries one-shotted (even if it had to auto correct some times)

----

This is what we did for testing:

- We start with cursor with a clean SE-2 install (no chain running, etc)
- First prompt:
```
I want to modify the exiting smart contract and add a delegate feature.

The owner of the contract will be able to set a delegate. And the the delegate will be able to witdraw from the contract (as the owner)

Then I want to create a custom UI (in the homepage) where the current delegate is display, and a input + button the update the delegate with a new Delegate Address.
```

(this should create a working version and should run chain / deploy /start)

- When is worklng, second prompt:`
```
Can you change the Owner to be "<WHATEVER_BURNER_ADDRESS>"?
```

(this should modify the script + run yarn deploy again)

- Last prompt:
```
How could I deploy this to Sepolia? Don't do it, just tell me the steps to follow.
```

(beside the basics, it should mention vercel and ipfs and hint to modify scaffold-config with the network).

----

Let's do a round of testing and see if we are happy with the results! Thanks all for working on this <3

items.body:
Thanks for exploring this, Rinat! Great job!!

Took a quick high-level look as you suggested. I think it's good to discuss and have a consensus before moving forward

> What do you think about that approach at all? Is it fit for us? Maybe some other ideas?

I like the approach, and I think this could make a lot of sense. I agree with the PROS / CONS. 

----

Something that we could discuss: where should we draw the line between just tailwind classes & components.

=> It's clear to me that modals (and similar) should be a Component (because they have some custom styling + "JS" functionality). 

=>  On the other side, it's not that clear for things like buttons, since it's _only_ styling. I guess the alternative would be to create some extra utility classes (using `@apply`?) like btn-primary, btn-sm, etc. This applies to things like badges, links, (tooltips?), etc.

I wonder if there would be a nice dynamic way to create variations with themes/colors/sizes for all of these utility classes.

Pushing back on myself: if we are expecting people to use either raw TW or Shadcn, maybe the approach of having `button`, etc as components is not a bad idea.

But yes, for me, not relying on custom components for simpler things seems better. I feel that it makes SE-2 less opinionated and closer to HTML / CSS. People can always create their own components (custom, shadcn, etc)

Anyway, just opening the discussion! Let me know what you all think!

Thanks again!!!

items.author: carletex

items.body:
Hey Tam,

Before going into technical details, I have to say that your attitude here comes as a surprise to me. Not sure where that's coming from, but definitely not something we are used to inside the BG. I want to think that this would sound different in a conversation, and your writing might sound worse than it really is.

I get that if you are only working on this, you feel left aside when we are not paying attention to your PR/issue. But we are a team working on dozens of issues / PR / projects inside the BG, and we prioritize and tackle things as we consider is the best way.

Ok, back to the tech details:

> I pinged @carletex about it, who said
> > Cool, that makes sense! I think the goal of the PR is great, so that's a big thumbs up!

> Therefore I spent 2-3 weeks to finalise the PR, but now you say that the idea is not a good one.

No one is telling you that. We all thought this was a good idea, but what Shiv is telling you here is that this approach doesn't work for us. It completely breaks the core principles of the `create-eth` projects. This PR hacks the way `create-eth` works, and we don't want that at all. This is something we have been discussing a lot: maybe the last time was here https://github.com/scaffold-eth/create-eth/issues/170, which was sparked by your issue.

> Also, with the current extension system, my demo branch cannot be turned into an extension.

That's a different problem. As you can see on the beta branch, we are rewriting a bunch of things on the template system to allow more use cases (feedback from extension builders). Again #170

---

Shiv gave you really good feedback here, detailing how this feature should work: https://github.com/scaffold-eth/create-eth/pull/205#issuecomment-2671047654, but it seems that you ignored it. That's how I thought this would work: since we already have `yarn create-extension` working, we should just tweak it a bit to support projects not started with create-eth (probably creating a diff between last commit and {commitHash} would work)

---

Leaving the most important part for the end: I'm really open to discuss tech details, iterate, argue, disagree etc, but if you want to collaborate with us, please be kind in your messages. Some of us worked really hard to assemble a tight team with good communication and attitude, and I won't let anything disturb that.

Thanks.

items.prTitle: Mark SRE build as BG-granted when a grant is completed

This works, and I know that it's very tempting to do so... but this is a bad practice in software (Tight coupling / layering violation). Basically, you are tying a database call with external side effects (changes non-atomic, harder to test, etc)

The easiest fix will be to move this to the route handler that it's using the "reviewGrant" function. Routes handlers can be seen as the "orchestration layers" so they can call different parts of the system.

items.body: Looking pretty good!! Thanks Port <3 Some things that I see. 1. Let's add a bit more space between the start and the begining of the columns. At least something like this 2. Let's place the tooltip in another position. Usually you hover the challenges from top to bottom. It's a bit weird to just run over the tooltip when hovering (and also hides the next item). Maybe on the right? 3. I think we could have better descriptions for the tootlip. I think we can be more specific about what you are going to learn / need to apply. (we can also remove the "mint your flag", "interact with challenge X", etc). IF not, it feels a bit vague? Some examples: "Mint your flag in this unverified contract." => "Analyze the bytecode of a unverified contract" or just "bytecode on unverified contract" "Mint your flag using the right signature." => "Craft a signature of a known PK" or just "Crafting signatures" Really open on this one, what do you think? We can also update the descriptions in another PRs. cc @portdeveloper @damianmarti
items.author: carletex

Merging, thanks!!!

items.prTitle: Add wipe script and commands to wipe or wipe+import
items.body:
A couple of questions:

1. Is it possible to make this dynamic? (delete the data from all the tables, without the need of hardcoding  companies, jobs). Not a big deal, but it'd be nice if possible
2. Deleting the data is enough, right? If we change the schema, we can wipe the data + drizzle push, right? (I mean, no need to delete the actual tables)
items.author: carletex

items.prTitle: Add wipe script and commands to wipe or wipe+import
items.body:
Thinking if we need this, since you might want to do something else after wipe content. 

But it's a nice idea to have a command to do the full set up. but maybe we need:

`yarn db:wipe-content && yarn drizzle-kit push && yarn db:import-sheet`?
items.author: carletex

items.prTitle: Add wipe script and commands to wipe or wipe+import
items.body:
How easy is it to add a confirmation?

Something like:

"This will delete all the data from the Database. Are you sure... blahblah?"

And then click Enter or Y or whatever to proceed.
items.author: carletex

items.prTitle: Add wipe script and commands to wipe or wipe+import
items.body:
Had to add 4e98a0588ba6 to exit the process with an error code.

If not, even if you cancel the "wipe" the other commands (push & import sheet) will still run.

This is looking great @ChangoMan ! Thank you.

A few comments / ideas:

- Let's change "Future Advertisement Here" => "Your Ad here" (or Advertisement)
- Could we add a smaller ad section here? (between companies and newsletter)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/9618c7a2-54e0-4d60-ba8b-f2a0271ad558)
- Could we add a "Your featured job post here" at the top of the list?
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e20fa778-a655-4b29-961d-373f1e381809)
- This is the multisig for the donations: 0xb66879142aE4f8B4C0A11B773942499831367606 (live in multiple networks). Not sure what's the best option to handle this. For now a link to Etherescan / Rainbow could be good (and then we can thing about building somehting ourselves, like a page with a QR / connect wallet / whatever)
- Could you change the style of the "Donate" link? Instead of a regular link, a button with some background.


I think all of these are small things, but also feel free to leave stuff for the next PR.

Thanks man!

items.prTitle: use slug for companies and jobs
items.body:
If you update the company, this will generate an incorrect slug (it will use the old company name).

Maybe a better approach is to compare the name & company from `job` and `existingJob`. If they are !=, then generate a new slug, if not, don't update it.
